content: Act as a helpful AI assistant

In Julia, You are given a DataFrame `df_cars` with car data with columns `manufacturer` and `model`. Write a function audi_filter that filters down the dataset to only the rows with manufacturer “audi” and model being “a4 or “a4 quattro”, then it should create a new column `audi_a4_type` that equals `true` across all rows. Then return the resulting DataFrame.

Here's a function in Julia that filters the dataset according to your requirements and adds a new column `audi_a4_type` with all values as `true`:
```julia
using DataFrames

function audi_filter(df::DataFrame)
    audis = filter(row -> row.manufacturer == "audi" && (row.model == "a4" || row.model == "a4 quattro"), df)
    for row in eachrow(audis)
        row[:audi_a4_type] = true
    end
    return audis
end
```
You can use this function by passing your `df_cars` DataFrame as an argument like this:
```julia
filtered_df = audi_filter(df_cars)
```
This will return a new filtered DataFrame containing only the rows with manufacturer "audi" and model being "a4" or "a4 quattro", along with the new column `audi_a4_type`.
